technical_concept: Creating commits with 'git commit' to save a snapshot of staged changes to the repository history.

challenge.task: Create a file called 'report.txt', stage it, and commit it with the message 'Initial report'.
challenge.hint: Stage your changes first, then commit with a descriptive message.
challenge.solution: touch report.txt && git add report.txt && git commit -m "Initial report"

dialogue.line: I've got evidence staged and ready. But it's not official until I seal the case file. How do I make it permanent?
That's where commits come in, Detective. A commit is like closing a case file and stamping it with a date and summary. Everything staged gets locked into the permanent record—forever.
So once I commit, it can't be changed?
That's the idea. Every commit gets a unique ID, a timestamp, and a message explaining what changed. Use 'git commit -m "Your message here"' to create a commit with a description.
The message is important, I'm guessing?

Critical. Think of it like writing a case summary. 'Fixed bug' is vague—useless six months from now. 'Fixed login timeout issue affecting mobile users' tells the whole story. Future you will thank present you.
What if I need to see all my commits later?
'git log' shows your entire commit history—every case you've closed, in order. It's your permanent record, your paper trail, your proof that you did the work.
Alright. Let me create report.txt, stage it, and commit it with a proper message.
My changes are staged. How do I save them permanently to the repository timeline?
You must create a commit. A commit is a snapshot—a frozen moment in your codebase's history, immutable and timestamped.
Think of it as creating a save point in time, Engineer. Everything in your staging area becomes part of the permanent historical record.
How do I create this snapshot?
Use 'git commit -m "message"'. The -m flag provides a commit message—a mandatory description of what changed. This message becomes part of the permanent record.
Commit messages should be descriptive. 'Fixed issue' is insufficient. 'Resolved oxygen regulator calibration error in sector 7' provides context for future engineers.
Can I review my commit history?
Affirmative. 'git log' displays the complete timeline—every commit, message, author, and timestamp. Your permanent operational record.
Understood. Creating report.txt, staging it, and committing to timeline.
My documents are staged upon thy table! Now I command thee—seal them in thy eternal chronicles!
So shall it be, my lord! With 'git commit', I shall inscribe thy changes into the permanent annals! But first—thou must provide a message, a declaration of what thou hast wrought!
A message? What manner of inscription dost thou require?
A summary, sire! Use 'git commit -m "thy message here"'. This declaration shall accompany thy commit throughout eternity. Future scholars will read it and understand thy intent!
Should I write 'fixed stuff' and be done with it?

Nay, my lord! Such vagueness dishonors the archive! Write instead: 'Resolved the authentication scroll corruption in the eastern provinces.' Be specific! Be descriptive! The future depends upon thy clarity!
Can I consult past commits, to see what I inscribed before?
'git log' reveals all! Every commit, every message, every author—the complete history laid bare like an illuminated manuscript!
Then let me create report.txt, stage it, and commit it with a message most eloquent!
My file is staged. Now what?
Now you commit. That's when your changes actually get saved to Git's permanent history. It's called a 'commit' because unlike Kevin, Git actually follows through.
Use 'git commit -m "Your message"'. The -m flag lets you add a message describing what you changed. And please, make it useful.
What counts as useful?
Not 'stuff', not 'changes', not 'fixed it'. Tell me what you actually did. 'Added user authentication' is good. 'did some work' is how Kevin does it.
Your commit message is documentation. Six months from now, when something breaks, you'll be reading through commit history trying to figure out what changed. Help your future self out.
Can I see my old commits?
'git log' shows everything. Every commit, every message, every mistake Kevin made. It's like a diary, except it actually happened and you can't delete it.
Got it. Let me create report.txt, stage it, and commit it with a real message.
